subject: Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... I m curious, do you find this rude? http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/6415 To me, it smacks of self-righteousness and shameless self-promotion. I
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Bill de hÓra <dehora@e...> wrote:
> To me Mike, you're coming across as rude.

I'm curious, do you find this rude?
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/6415

To me, it smacks of self-righteousness and shameless self-promotion.

I didn't come here to have some guy and his buddy disparage the ideas
that I offer without offering anything in exchange other than, "This
is how it is. Buy my book!"


Someone saying they're too
> busy to write an article right now is perfectly good reason - no-
one
> here has to answer your questions in your timeframe.


I think if a person jumps into a discussion and says, "Your approach
sucks. Buy my book!" they should at least explain why. That might
actually be helpful to others.


> Yet, I haven't
> seen any explanation as to what is inferior in your approach -
> asserting it's inferior does not make it so.


I couldn't agree more.


> I also found the waving
> of the moderator stick distasteful; it's far too early for that.
>
> A suggestion - stop posting for 24 hours on this thread, then come
> back to it.
>
> Bill de hÓra


Whoops, too late for that! Heheh.

For the record, I never said I disagreed with what Dave and J. B. are
advocating. I never said I didn't like them personally, either.
It's the delivery of their message I find curious. It seems more
geared toward self-interest than equitable exchange or mutual benefit.

Mike
